factoid: The speaker will go to ruin as soon as possible.
The speaker says that it is not the addressed person's business.
The speaker says that it will not be the addressed person, but the speaker will suffer.
The speaker says that the addressed person should leave the speaker alone.
The speaker says that the speaker hates the addressed person.
Sónya moaned "Natásha" in an agitated manner.
Natásha says "I hate you, I hate you."
Natásha says "You are my enemy forever."
Natásha ran out of the room.
Natásha did not speak to Sónya again.
Natásha avoided Sónya.
Natásha had an expression of agitated surprise and guilt while going about the house.
Natásha took up one occupation, then another, and abandoned them all at once.
Sónya found it hard but watched Natásha and did not let her out of sight.
The day before the count was to return, Sónya noticed that Natásha sat by the drawing room window all morning as if expecting something.
Natásha made a sign to an officer who drove past.
Sónya identified the officer as Anatole.
Sónya began watching Natásha more attentively.
Sónya noticed that at dinner and that evening Natásha was in a strange and unnatural state.
Natásha answered questions at random.
Natásha began sentences she did not finish.
Natásha laughed at everything.
After tea, Sónya noticed a housemaid at Natásha's door who was timidly waiting to let her pass.
Sónya let the housemaid go in.
Sónya learned at the door that another letter had been delivered.
Sónya realized that Natásha had a dreadful plan for that evening.
Sónya knocked at Natásha's door.
Natásha did not let Sónya in.
Sónya thought that Natásha would run away with him.
Sónya thought that Natásha is capable of anything.
Sónya observed that Natásha had a particularly pathetic and resolute expression on her face that day.
Sónya remembered that Natásha cried as she said goodbye to Uncle.
Sónya thought that Natásha intends to elope with him.
Sónya considered writing to Kurágin demanding an explanation because the count is away.
Sónya considered writing to Pierre as Prince Andrew had asked her to in case of misfortune.
Sónya considered that Natásha had already refused Bolkónski and sent a letter to Princess Mary yesterday.
Sónya noted that Uncle is away.
Sónya thought that telling Márya Dmítrievna, who had faith in Natásha, would be terrible.
Sónya thought that she must prove that she remembers the family's goodness and that she loves Nicholas.
Sónya thought that if she does not sleep for three nights, she would hold Natásha back by force and would not let the family be disgraced.
Anatole had recently moved to Dólokhov's.
Dólokhov arranged the plan for Natalie Rostóva's abduction a few days before.
Dólokhov made preparations for the abduction of Natalie Rostóva.
On the day Sónya resolved to safeguard Natásha, the plan for Natalie Rostóva's abduction was to be executed.
Natásha promised to come out to Kurágin at the back porch at ten that evening.
Kúrágin was to put Natásha into a troyka and drive her forty miles to the village of Kámenka.
In Kámenka an unfrocked priest was ready to perform a marriage ceremony over Natásha and her partner.
At Kámenka a relay of horses was waiting to take them to the Warsaw highroad.
From the Warsaw highroad they would hasten abroad with post horses.
Anatole had a passport.
Anatole had an order for post horses.
Anatole had ten thousand rubles taken from his sister.
Anatole had borrowed another ten thousand rubles with Dólokhov's help.
Khvóstikov was a retired petty official whom Dólokhov used in gambling transactions.
Makárin was a retired hussar who was kind, weak, and had an unbounded affection for Kurágin.
Khvóstikov and Makárin were sitting at tea in Dólokhov's front room.
Dólokhov sat in his large study with Persian rugs, bearskins, and weapons on the walls.
Dólokhov was wearing a traveling cloak and high boots.
Dólokhov was at an open desk with an abacus and some bundles of paper money.
Anatole had his uniform unbuttoned.
Anatole walked back and forth from the room where the witnesses were sitting, through the study, to the room behind where his French valet and others were packing the last of his things.
Dólokhov was counting money and noting something down.
Dólokhov said that Khvóstikov must have two thousand.
